CUMULATIVE CAPITAL DEVELOPMENT FUND
§ 36.01 FUND ESTABLISHED.
   There is established a Cumulative Capital Development Fund pursuant to IC
36-9-15-5 (as added by Public Law 44-1984).
(Ord. 1987-10, passed 8-24-87; Am. Ord. 1988-9, passed 6-13-88; Am. Ord. 4-
1991, passed 6-24-91; Am. Ord. 1994-1, passed 6-13-94)
             
Editor's note: IC 36-9-15-5 was repealed by P.1.17-1995, effective July 1,
1995. Statutory cumulative fund provisions are currently set forth in IC 6-1.1-
41.
§ 36.02 PURPOSES OF FUND.
   The purposes of the Cumulative Capital Development Fund shall be those
purposes set forth in IC 36-9-16-2 and IC 36-9-16-3 which provide as follows:
   (A)   A municipality may establish a cumulative building or sinking fund or
cumulative capital improvement funds to provide money for one or more of the
following purposes:
      (1)   To purchase, construct, equip, and maintain buildings for municipal
purposes.
      (2)   To acquire the land, and any improvements on it, that are necessary
for the construction of municipal buildings.
      (3)   To demolish any improvements of land acquired under this
subchapter, and to level, grade, and prepare the land for the construction of a
municipal building.
      (4)   To acquire land or rights-of-way to be used as a public way or
other means of ingress or egress to land acquired for the construction of a
municipal building.
      (5)   To improve or construct any public way or other means of ingress or
egress to land acquired for the construction of a municipal building.
   (B)   A municipality may also establish cumulative capital funds to provide
money for one or more of the following purposes:
      (1)   To acquire land or rights-of-way to be used for public ways or
sidewalks.
      (2)   To construct and maintain public ways or sidewalks.
      (3)   To acquire land or rights-of-way for the construction or sanitary
or storm sewers, or both.
      (4)   To construct and maintain sanitary or storm sewers, or both.
      (5)   To acquire, by purchase or lease, or to pay all or part of the
purchase price of a utility.
      (6)   To purchase or lease land, buildings, or rights-of-way for the use
of any utility that is acquired or operated by the municipality.
      (7)   To purchase or acquire land, with or without buildings, for park or
recreation purposes.
      (8)   To purchase, lease, or pay all or part of the purchase price of
motor vehicles for the use of the Police or Fire Department, or both, including
ambulances and firefighting vehicles with the necessary equipment, ladders, and
hoses.
      (9)   To retire in whole or part any general obligation bonds of the
municipality that were issued for the purpose of acquiring or constructing
improvements or properties that would qualify for the use of cumulative capital
funds.
      (10)   To purchase or lease equipment and other nonconsumable personal
property needed by the municipality for any public transporta- tion use.
(Ord. 1987-10, passed 8-24-87; Am. Ord. 1988-9, passed 6-13-88; Am. Ord. 4-
1991, passed 6-24-91; Am. Ord. 1994-1, passed 6-13-94)
§ 36.03 LEVY.
   The levy imposed shall be as follows:
   (A)   $.15 per $100 of assessed valuation for 1995.
   (B)   $.15 per $100 of assessed valuation for 1996.
   (C)   $.15 per $100 of assessed valuation for 1997.
(Ord. 1987-10, passed 8-24-87; Am. Ord. 1988-9, passed 6-13-88; Am. Ord. 4-
1991, passed 6-24-91; Am. Ord. 1994-1, passed 6-13-94)
NON-REVERTING FUND FOR POLICE LAW ENFORCEMENT
CONTINUING EDUCATION PROGRAM FEES
§ 36.10 FUND ESTABLISHED.
   There is created, to be under the control of the Edinburgh Town Council, a
special non-reverting operating fund, as authorized in IC 5-2-8-2 for purpose
of a continuing education program for the Edinburgh Town Marshal and his
deputies.
(Ord. 1987-13, passed 12-14-87; Am. Ord. 1997-4, passed 8-25-97; Am. Ord. 2021-
10, passed 5-24-21)
§ 36.11 MONIES DEPOSITED IN USER FEE FUND.
   (A)   The program is funded by amounts appropriated under IC 33-37-8-4 and
fees collected under IC 9-17-2-12(e), IC 9-26-9-3, and IC 35-47-2-3.
   (B)   The Town Marshal of Edinburgh, which receives amounts based upon
claims for law enforcement continuing education funds under IC 33-37-8-4 or IC
33-37-8-6 shall deposit each fee collected into the fund per §
36.10.
(Ord. 1987-13, passed 12-14-87; Am. Ord. 1997-4, passed 8-25-97; Am. Ord. 2021-
10, passed 5-24-21)
§ 36.12 ADMINISTRATION BY CLERK-TREASURER.
   (A)   After application, approved by the Town Marshal and submitted on
proper claim forms to the Clerk-Treasurer and approved by the Town Council, the
Clerk-Treasurer shall transfer sufficient funds from the user fee fund to the
non-reverting fund established by this subchapter.
   (B)   The fund shall be administered by the Town Clerk-Treasurer in that the
Clerk-Treasurer is the fiscal officer of the town.
(Ord. 1987-13, passed 12-14-87; Am. Ord. 1997-4, passed 8-25-97; Am. Ord. 2021-
10, passed 5-24-21)
§ 36.13 APPROVAL OF CLAIM.
   Upon receipt of a claim submitted upon oath to the fiscal body Town Council
after the claim has been reviewed and allowed by the Town Marshal and signed by
the Marshal, the Town Council shall approve the claim, provided, however, that
the funds shall be used only to pay for the continuing law enforcement
education of the members of the Town Marshal's Department and equipment and
supplies for law enforcement purposes in accordance with IC 5-2-8-2 and IC 5-2-
8-6.
(Ord. 1987-13, passed 12-14-87; Am. Ord. 1997-4, passed 8-25-97; Am. Ord. 2021-
10, passed 5-24-21)
NON-REVERTING OPERATING FUND
§ 36.20 FUND ESTABLISHED.
   There is created, to be under the control of the Town Council, a special
Non-reverting Operating Fund as authorized in IC 36-10-3-20 and IC 36-10-3-22.
(Ord. 1988-5, passed 4-11-88; Am. Ord. 2002-11, passed 11-25-02)
§ 36.21 MONIES DEPOSITED IN FUND.
   Monies in the form of fees generated by the collection of monies procured
from the use of Parks and Recreation facilities and programs shall be
designated as softball, youth basketball, volleyball, aerobics/line dancing,
youth baseball, adult basketball, swim lessons/aquacize, karate, youth club,
donations, concessions and tennis and shall be deposited in the special Non-
reverting Operating Fund maintained by the town.
(Ord. 1988-5, passed 4-11-88; Am. Ord. 2002-11, passed 11-25-02)
§ 36.22 ADMINISTRATION OF FUNDS BY CLERK-TREASURER.
   The fund shall be administered by the Town Clerk-Treasurer in that the
Clerk-Treasurer is the fiscal officer of the town.
(Ord. 1988-5, passed 4-11-88; Am. Ord. 2002-11, passed 11-25-02)
§ 36.23 APPROVAL OF CLAIM.
   (A)   Upon receipt of a claim submitted upon oath to the Town Council after
that claim has been reviewed and allowed by the Parks and Recreation Director,
the Town Council shall approve that claim; provided, however, that those funds
shall be used to only pay for items pertaining to the programs listed in §36.21
as established by this subchapter.
   (B)   These items shall include but are not limited to the following:
      (1)   Supplies;
      (2)   Materials;
      (3)   Seasonal staff; and
      (4)   Playground equipment.
(Ord. 1988-5, passed 4-11-88; Am. Ord. 2002-11, passed 11-25-02)
§ 36.24 OTHER PURPOSES.
   This fund shall also be used for the purposes of acquiring land or making
specific capital improvements for the use of the programs listed in §36.21.
(Ord. 2002-11, passed 11-25-02)
NON-REVERTING OPERATING FIRE-EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES FUND
§ 36.30 FUND ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   Establishment. The Town Council hereby establishes a new fund entitled
the Non-reverting Operating Fire-Emergency Medical Services Fund under the
following provisions (herein referred to as new fund:
      (1)   The new fund shall be a non-reverting operating fund that is funded
with monies collected from the town's fire and EMS services;
      (2)   The monies currently on deposit in the former fund shall be
transferred to the new fund, and the former fund shall subsequently cease to
exist;
      (3)   The Fire Chief may, from time to time, submit a claim form with the
Town's Clerk-Treasurer to draw from the new fund. Any claim for draws from the
new fund shall be only for the following:
         (a)   Purchasing fire equipment for the town;
         (b)   Purchasing EMS equipment for the town;
         (c)   The purchase, construction, renovation, or addition to buildings
used by the town's fire and EMS personnel;
      (4)   No monies may be withdrawn from the new fund by the Fire Chief
unless a proper claim form is submitted to the town's Clerk- Treasurer;
      (5)   Upon the submittal of the claim from the Fire Chief, the town's
Clerk-Treasurer shall present said claim to the Council for approval;
      (6)   Upon approval by the Council, the town's Clerk-Treasurer shall
transfer the requested amounts from the new fund to the town's Fire and EMS
Operating Fund, and the Fire Chief shall use the requested amounts for the
purposes outlined on the submitted claim;
      (7)   Any monies left on deposit in the new fund at the end of the fiscal
year shall accumulate and remain in the new fund;
      (8)   The town's Clerk-Treasurer shall administer the new fund in that
the town's Clerk-Treasurer is the fiscal officer of the town;
   (B)   Statutory authority.
      (1)   IC 16-31-5-1 allows for the town to establish, operate, and
maintain emergency medical services and furthermore allows the town to
establish and provide for the collection of reasonable fees for emergency
ambulance services provided by the town.
      (2)   IC 36-8-14-2 allows for the town to establish a cumulative fund for
the benefit of the town's fire and EMS services for the purposes outlined in
division (A) of this section.
      (3)   No taxes are being levied by the town to fund the new fund, so the
requirements proscribed in IC 6-1.1-41 do not apply to the new fund.
   (C)   The Council finds that the new fund will be in the best interest of
the town and for the benefit of the public and residents of the town.
(Ord. 2011-1, passed 1-24-11)
PROMOTIONAL FUNDS
§ 36.45 AUTHORIZATION TO BUDGET AND EXPEND FUNDS.
   (A)   Pursuant to IC 36-7-2-7 the town departments of Town Council, Clerk-
Treasurer, Economic Development, Fire/EMT Departments are hereby authorized to
budget and expend funds subject to the claim procedure through the Town Council
for the promotion of the best interests of the town.
   (B)   The town departments of Town Council, Clerk-Treasurer, Economic
Development, Fire/EMT Departments are hereby authorized to budget for the funds
under the heading on the budget forms of "Promotion" or "Promotional" funds.
(Ord. 1994-2, passed 12-29-94)
§ 36.46 APPLICATION; APPROVAL.
   (A)   After the funds are budgeted by those named departments, the funds
shall only be expended after proper application and submission on proper claim
forms to the Clerk-Treasurer and approved by the Town Council. The funds shall
not be expended unless approved by the Town Council, either in the form of
prior approval or direction to department supervisors.
   (B)   The Town Council hereby promulgates the following promotional expenses
that can be paid from moneys appropriated for such purpose under this
subchapter:
      (1)   Up to two employee appreciation lunches, including food and drink
expenses, per calendar year;
      (2)   Events and celebrations relating to 4th of July;
      (3)   Annual Edinburgh Fall Festival;
      (4)   Annual Edinburgh Holiday of Lights;
      (5)   Donations to charitable organizations;
      (6)   Text program for the town.
      (7)   Any cause or activity that would be deemed by Town Council to be in
the best interest of the town.
   (C)   The Council will not approve and/or authorize excessive amounts
expended for employee meals, awards, gifts, and other amounts expended for
items not listed in this section.
(Ord. 1994-2, passed 12-29-94; Am. Ord. 2015-9, passed 11-23-15)
§ 36.47 ADMINISTERED BY CLERK-TREASURER.
   The budgets and funds shall be administered by the Town Clerk- Treasurer in
that the Clerk-Treasurer is the fiscal officer of the town.
(Ord. 1994-2, passed 12-29-94)
§ 36.48 FUNDS TO PROMOTE BEST INTERESTS OF TOWN.
   Upon receipt of a claim submitted upon oath to the fiscal body (Town
Council), and after the claim has been reviewed and allowed by the appropriate
department supervisor, the Town Council shall approve the claim, provided,
however, that the funds shall be used only for promoting the best interests of
the town, including economic development, tourism, utility development,
recreational development and intergovernmental cooperation.
(Ord. 1994-2, passed 12-29-94)
RIVERBOAT WAGERING TAX REVENUE SHARING FUND
§ 36.50 FUND ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   There is created, under the control of the Town Council, pursuant to
IC 36-1-8-9, a Riverboat Wagering Tax Revenue Sharing Fund.
   (B)   This fund shall be administered pursuant to IC 4-33-13-5, as amended
by the Town’s Clerk-Treasurer, and all expenses of administering the fund shall
be paid from money in the fund pursuant to IC 36-1-8-9(b).
(Ord. 2003-5, passed 8-25-03)
§ 36.51 PURPOSES OF FUND.
   The funds contained in the Riverboat Wagering Tax Revenue Sharing Fund shall
be used for the purposes contained in IC 4-33-13-5(e) as follows:
   (A)   To reduce the property tax levy of the town or county for a particular
year, but a property tax reduction under this subsection does not reduce the
maximum levy of the town, or county under IC 6-1.1-18.5;
   (B)   For deposit in a special fund or allocation fund or allocation fund
created under IC 8-22-3.5, IC 36-7-14, IC 36-7-14.5, IC 36-7-15.1, and IC 36-7-
30 to provide funding for additional credits for property tax replacement in
property tax increment allocation areas or debt repayment;
   (C)   To fund sewer and water projects, including storm water management
projects;
   (D)   For police and fire pensions; and
   (E)   To carry out any governmental purpose for which the money is
appropriated by the fiscal body of the town or county. Money used under this
subsection does not reduce the property tax levy of the town or county for a
particular year or reduce the maximum levy of the town or county under IC 6-
1.1-18.5.
(Ord. 2003-5, passed 8-25-03)
OTHER NON-REVERTING FUNDS
§ 36.60 NON-REVERTING OPERATING FUND RELATED TO TIMBERGATE GOLF COURSE.
   (A)   There is created, to be under the control of the Town Council, a
special non-reverting operating fund, as authorized in IC 33-19-6-7 and 33-19-
8.1 et seq.
   (B)   Monies received from a contractual agreement with Amos Investment
Corporation for subdivision-related construction activities during the joint
construction of the Timbergate Golf Course by the town's redevelopment
authority shall be deposited in the fund.
   (C)   Upon receipt of invoice by the contractor, the town shall cause these
same funds to be dispersed to said contractor in the appropriately approved
amount as certified by the town. Contract retainage shall be transferred by
check to a separate escrow account located at NBD Bank, Edinburgh, Indiana,
until such time those monies are releasable by the contract.
(Ord. 1997-7, passed 8-25-97)
§ 36.61 NON-REVERTING OPERATING FUND RELATED AN AQUATICS CENTER.
   (A)   There is created, to be under the control of the Town Council, a
special non-reverting operating fund, as authorized in IC 33-19-6-7 and 33-19-
8.1 et seq.
   (B)   Deposits to this fund shall be comprised of monies received from
Midwest Bankers Group, representing the balance of the lease/purchase for the
Edinburgh Aquatics Center. The balance of the lease is $82,811.27, which will
be delivered from Midwest Bankers Group to the town for deposit in this non-
reverting fund.
   (C)   Funds deposited in the non-reverting fund shall be dispersed to Spear
Corporation in compliance with the existing contract based on the contractor's
finalization of work. Also, the Edinburgh Electric Utility shall receive
reimbursement in the amount of $22,187.66 for electrical equipment purchased
and installed by the utility. Any remaining funds may be utilized to purchase
pool operation-related capital equipment or be committed to the bi-annual lease
payments for the pool facility.
(Ord. 1997-9, passed 10-27-97)
§ 36.62 NON-REVERTING FUND RELATED TO THE EDINBURGH REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY.
   (A)    here is created, to be under the control of the Town Council of the
Town of Edinburgh and its Edinburgh Redevelopment Authority, a special non-
reverting operating fund named Timbergate Operations NRO as authorized in IC
33-19-6-7 and IC 33-19-8.1 et seq. The purpose of the fund is to accommodate
start-up expenses of the Timbergate Golf Course Operation including but not
limited to the following: temporary club house, temporary cart storage,
equipment, supplies, pro-shop fixturing, furniture, goods to be sold,
landscaping, irrigation work, decorating expense, maintenance building
expansion costs and club house construction costs.
   (B)   The fund will receive funds temporarily loaned from the Electric Cash
Reserve Fund as set forth in Resolution 1999-2. The fund may also receive
donated funds from private entities, appropriate transfers from other town
departments, golf operations revenue and Golf Course Construction/Retainage
account transfers as determined appropriate.
   (C)   The fund shall exist until such time that all start-up expenses have
been satisfied and all loans repaid to the Electric Cash Reserve account as set
forth in Resolution 1999-2. Upon finalization of the above details, the fund
shall be closed by Council action.
(Ord. 1999-1, passed 2-8-99)
§ 36.63 NON-REVERTING FUND RELATED TO THE TOWN COUNCIL.
   (A)   There is created, to be under the control of the Town Council of
Edinburgh, a special non-reverting operating fund as authorized in IC 33-19-6-
7 and IC 33-19-8.1 et seq.
   (B)   Deposits to this fund shall be comprised of monies received from Henry
Conover and various other fund raising efforts of the Town or its constituents.
   (C)   Funds deposited in the non-reverting fund shall be dispersed for
construction of the future Conover Memorial Park, located on Timbergate Golf
Course and all other related costs for said project.
(Ord. 1998-5, passed 5-11-98)
§ 36.64 K-9 NON-REVERTING OPERATING (NRO) FUND.
   (A)   Creation of Fund 299 K-9 Non-Reverting Operating (NRO) Fund. There is
hereby established a "K-9 Non-Reverting Operating (NRO) Fund". The fund shall
be used to deposit both past and future donations as well as other revenues and
to disburse funds for expenses relating to a K-9 unit(s).
   (B)   Use of the Funds. All funds deposited into the K-9 NRO Fund shall be
used for the acquisition of K-9 police dogs, care and maintenance of K-9 police
dogs, the purchase of necessary equipment related to K-9 police dogs, and
training of the K-9 police dogs and the police officer assigned to handle the
K-9 police dog. Use of funds shall be dispersed only upon approval of a claim
by the Edinburgh Town Council.
   (C)   Appropriations and purchases. The Town Council of the Town of
Edinburgh may authorize the expenditure of funds from K-9 NRO Fund by
appropriations made in the same manner as other funds are appropriated that
receive distributions, upon making a finding that the proposed use of the funds
is consistent with the intent of the fund.
(Ord. 2022-5, passed 6-27-22)
RAINY DAY FUND
§ 36.70 CREATION OF THE RAINY DAY FUND.
   There is hereby established a Rainy Day Fund to receive transfers of unused
and unencumbered funds raised by a general or special tax levy on taxable
property within the town, whenever the purpose of such tax levy has been
fulfilled and an unused and unencumbered balance remains.
(Ord. 2004-4, passed 6-14-04; Am. Ord. 2015-8, passed 10-26-15)
§ 36.71 PURPOSES OF THE FUND.
   The Rainy Day Fund may be used for any lawful purpose in the operation of
the town and its various departments, including but not limited to, salaries
and wages, costs of services, supplies, equipment, capital improvements,
repairs and similar expenditures.
(Ord. 2004-4, passed 6-14-04; Am. Ord. 2015-8, passed 10-26-15)
§ 36.72 TRANSFERS TO THE FUND.
   Transfers to the Rainy Day Fund may be made anytime throughout the year by
ordinance or resolution. The Town Council shall determine the amount, if any,
of any unused and unencumbered funds available to be transferred to the Rainy
Day Fund, which transfer may not exceed more than 10% of the town's total
budget for the fiscal year.
(Ord. 2004-4, passed 6-14-04; Am. Ord. 2015-8, passed 10-26-15)
§ 36.73 APPROPRIATIONS.
   The Town Council may authorize the expenditure of funds from the Rainy Day
Fund by appropriations made in the same manner as other funds are appropriated
that receive tax moneys, upon making a finding that the proposed use of the
funds is consistent with the intent of the fund.
(Ord. 2004-4, passed 6-14-04; Am. Ord. 2015-8, passed 10-26-15)
EDINBURGH PARKS MEMORIAL FUND
§ 36.80 FUND ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   The Edinburgh Parks Memorial Fund is hereby established for use by the
town under the following provisions.
   (B)   The Clerk-Treasurer of the Town of Edinburgh shall create a
specifically designated fund entitled the “Edinburgh Parks Memorial Fund” into
which all public or private donations made payable to the “Edinburgh Parks
Memorial Fund” for the purpose of constructing a memorial for Ethan Powell at
the Sports Complex; constructing memorials at the town's public parks;
maintenance of the memorials; and to provide financial assistance to children
of the town who wish to participate in activities of the Parks and Recreation
Department, but who are financially unable to afford the registration fees,
equipment, or supplies that are required for the activity, shall be deposited.
   (C)   The Edinburgh Parks Memorial Fund will be managed, reported, and
accounted for by the Town Clerk-Treasurer in that the town's Clerk-Treasurer is
the fiscal officer of the town.
   (D)   The Superintendent of the Town Parks and Recreation Department may
from time to time, submit a claim form with the town's Clerk-Treasurer to draw
from the Edinburgh Parks Memorial Fund. Any claim for draws from the Edinburgh
Parks Memorial Fund shall be only for the following:
      (1)   Construction of a memorial for Ethan Powell at the Sports Complex;
      (2)   Construction of memorials at the town's public parks;
      (3)   Maintenance of memorials constructed pursuant to this section; or
      (4)   To provide financial assistance to children of the town who wish to
participate in activities of the Town Parks and Recreation Department, but who
are financially unable to afford the registration fees, equipment, or supplies
that are required for the activity.
   (E)   Financial assistance to children of the town who wish to participate
in activities of the Parks and Recreation Department, but who are financially
unable to afford the registration fees, equipment, or supplies that are
required for the activity shall be authorized only after the memorial for Ethan
Powell has been constructed and only if sufficient funds are reserved for
maintenance of any other memorials constructed pursuant to this section.
   (F)   No monies may be withdrawn from the Edinburgh Parks Memorial Fund
until and unless a proper claim form is submitted to the town's Clerk-
Treasurer.
   (G)   Upon submittal of the claim form from the Superintendent of the Parks
and Recreation Department, the town's Clerk-Treasurer shall present said claim
to the Town Council for approval.
   (H)   Upon approval by the Town Council, the town's Clerk-Treasurer shall
pay the claim.
   (I)   The funds donated to the Edinburgh Parks Memorial Fund shall not be
commingled with any other monies received by the town.
   (J)   The Edinburgh Parks Memorial Fund balance is a non-reverting operating
fund and all monies deposited in the Edinburgh Parks Memorial Fund may only be
used for the purposes authorized by this section.
   (K)   Any monies left on deposit in the Edinburgh Parks Memorial Fund at the
end of the fiscal year shall accumulate and remain in the Edinburgh Parks
Memorial Fund.
   (1)   Income from investments of the Edinburgh Parks Memorial Fund shall be
receipted into the same Edinburgh Parks Memorial Fund.
   (M)   Upon termination of the Edinburgh Parks Memorial Fund by subsequent
ordinance, the balance remaining the fund shall be transferred to the Park and
Recreation operating fund.
(Ord. 2014-6, passed 4-28-14)
LOIT SPECIAL DISTRIBUTION FUND
§ 36.85 FUND ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   Creation of Fund 257 LOIT Special Distribution Fund. There is hereby
established a LOIT Special Distribution Fund to receive special distributions
of Local Option Income- Tax pursuant to Senate Enrolled Act 67 and any other
funding source not specifically prohibited by law.
   (B)   Purposes of the Fund. Expenditures from this Fund are restricted to
allowable purposes per IC 6-3.6-9-17(h)(1)(A) as follows:
      (1)   Engineering, land acquisition, construction, resurfacing,
maintenance, restoration, or rehabilitation of both local and arterial road and
street systems;
      (2)   The payment of principal and interest on bonds sold primarily to
finance road, street, or thoroughfare projects;
      (3)   Any local costs required to undertake a recreational or reservoir
road project under IC 8-23-5;
      (4)   The purchase, rental, or repair of highway equipment;
      (5)   Providing a match for a grant from the local road and bridge
matching grant fund under IC 8-23-30;
      (6)   Capital projects for aviation related property or facilities,
including capital projects of a Board of Aviation Commissioners established
under IC 8-22-2 or an Airport Authority established under IC 82-22-3-1.
   (C)   Appropriations. The Town Council may authorize the expenditure of
funds from the LOIT Special Distribution Fund by appropriations made in the
same manner as other funds are appropriated that receive tax moneys, upon
making a finding that the proposed use of the funds is consistent with the
intent of the Fund.
(Ord. 2016-4, passed 5-23-16)
LOCAL ROAD AND BRIDGE GRANT MATCHING FUND
§ 36.90 FUND ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   Creation of Fund 258 - Local Road and Bridge Matching Grant Fund.
There is hereby established a Local Road and Bridge Grant Matching Fund to
receive grant monies from the 2016 Community Crossings Matching Grant and
funding from the Rainy Day Fund, MVH Fund, Local R & S Fund, LOIT Special
Distribution 257 Fund and any other funding source not specifically prohibited
by law.
   (B)   Purposes of the Fund. Expenditures from this Fund will be used for
road and street projects approved in the grant and will be used as provided for
in the grant approval.
   (C)   Disposition of unused funds. After completion of the approved project
(s), any unused funds will be disposed of based upon the pro-rata share of the
local match and the state match. The portion of unused funds which represents
the share of the local match will revert to the fund from which the original
deposit was made. The portion of unused funds which represents the share of the
state match will be paid to the State Treasurer.
(Ord. 2017-2, passed 2-27-17)

establishment of the "NRO Indiana Market Place II" to receive transfers of all
real property tax revenues and revenues from any utility services of the
annexation area ("Marketplace Fund").
   (B)   Purposes of the Fund. The Marketplace Fund may be used for any lawful
purpose in the operation of the town and its various departments, including,
but not limited to, salaries and wages, costs of services, supplies, equipment,
capital improvements, repairs and similar expenditures provided however, that
the Town Council shall first consider applying such funds to support the
police, ambulance/rescue, and fire services provided to the annexation area.

ARP CORONAVIRUS LOCAL RECOVERY FUND
§ 36.115 FUND ESTABLISHED.
   Creation of Fund 176 - ARP Coronavirus Local Fiscal Recovery Fund. Pursuant
to State Examiner Directive 2021-1, there is hereby established a special, non-
reverting fund designated the "ARP Coronavirus Local Fiscal Recovery Fund,"
fund number 176;
(Ord. 2021-9, passed 4-26-21)
§ 36.116 USE OF FUNDS.
   (A)   The use of funds shall be in accordance with the following purposes
set forth in Section 603(c) of the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 801 et seq.),
as added by Section 9901 of the ARP:
      (1)   To respond to the public health emergency with respect to the
Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) or its negative economic impacts, including
assistance to households, small businesses, and nonprofits, or aid to impacted
industries such as tourism, travel, and hospitality;
      (2)   To respond to workers performing essential work during the COVID-19
public health emergency by providing premium pay to eligible workers of the
town that are performing such essential work, or by providing grants to
eligible employers that have eligible workers who perform essential work;
      (3)   For the provision of government services to the extent of the
reduction in revenue of the town due to the COVID-19 public health emergency
relative to revenues collected in the most recent full fiscal year of the town
prior to the emergency; or
      (4)   To make necessary investments in water, sewer, or broadband
infrastructure.
   (B)   The term "ELIGIBLE WORKERS" means those workers needed to maintain
continuity of operations of essential critical infrastructure sectors and
additional sectors as each chief executive officer of the town may designate as
critical to protect the health and well-being of the residents of the town.
   (C)   Before money in the fund is disbursed, the Town Council must
appropriate the money in the fund for a use consistent with Section 603(c) of
the Social Security Act (42 U.S.C. 801 et seq.), as added by Section 9901 of
the ARP, as stated in this section and the plan adopted by the town.
   (D)   All disbursements shall be made from the ARP Grant Fund. Money shall
not be transferred to another fund of the town.
   (E)   The grant funding may be used to cover costs incurred by the town
prior to December 31, 2024.
(Ord. 2021-9, passed 4-26-21; Am. Ord. 2021-17, passed 9-27-21)
§ 36.117 APPROPRIATIONS AND PURCHASES.
      (1)   The Town Council of the Town of Edinburgh may authorize the
expenditure of funds from ARP Coronavirus Local Fiscal Recovery Fund by
appropriations made in the same manner as other funds are appropriated that
receive tax distributions, upon making a finding that the proposed use of the
funds is consistent with the intent of the Fund.
      (2)   Plan. The Town Council shall adopt a plan which provides details
for the use of these funds.
(Ord. 2021-9, passed 4-26-21; Am. Ord. 2021-17, passed 9-27-21)
MAINTENANCE AND PERFORMANCE BOND FUND
§ 36.125 FUND ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   Creation of Fund 801 Maintenance and Performance Bond Fund. There is
hereby established a "Maintenance and Performance Bond Fund" to receive
distributions from individuals or businesses required to post a bond.
   (B)   Sources of Fund. Fund sources may include performance, maintenance,
surety, or other such bonds and related interest earnings (if applicable).
   (C)   Purposes of the Fund. Expenditures from this Fund are restricted to
payments of performance, maintenance, surety, or other such bonds and related
interest earnings (if applicable); or transfer to the respective fund the bond
is intended to cover if terms of performance bond are not met (e.g., if the
bond is to cover water infrastructure, the funds would be transferred to the
Water Operating Fund).
   (D)   Appropriations. The Town Council of the Town of Edinburgh may
authorize the expenditure of funds from the Maintenance and Performance Bond
Fund by appropriations made in the same manner as other funds upon making a
finding that the proposed use of the funds is consistent with the intent of the
Fund.
(Ord. 2021-12, passed 6-28-21)
TIF FUNDS
§ 36.130 TIF - US 31 ALLOCATION AREA FUND.
   (A)   Creation of Fund 295 TIF - US 31 Allocation Area Fund. There is hereby
established a "TIF - US 31 Allocation Area Fund" to receive tax distributions
from the US 31 TIF District.
   (B)   Purposes of the Fund. Per IC 36-7-14-39(b)(4), funds from a TIF fund
may only be used by the Edinburgh Redevelopment Commission for one or more of
the following:
      (1)   Pay the principal of and interest on any obligations payable solely
from allocated tax proceeds which are incurred by the redevelopment district
for the purpose of financing or refinancing the redevelopment of that
allocation area.
      (2)   Establish, augment, or restore the debt service reserve for bonds
payable solely or in part from allocated tax proceeds in that allocation area.
      (3)   Pay the principal of and interest on bonds payable from allocated
tax proceeds in that allocation area and from the special tax levied under
section IC 36-7-14-27.
      (4)   Pay the principal of and interest on bonds issued by the unit to
pay for local public improvements that are physically located in or physically
connected to that allocation area.
      (5)   Pay premiums on the redemption before maturity of bonds payable
solely or in part from allocated tax proceeds in that allocation area.
      (6)   Make payments on leases payable from allocated tax proceeds in that
allocation area under section IC 36-7-14-25.2.
      (7)   Reimburse the unit for expenditures made by it for local public
improvements (which include buildings, parking facilities, and other items
described in IC 36-7-14-25.1(a)) that are physically located in or physically
connected to that allocation area.
      (8)   Reimburse the unit for rentals paid by it for a building or parking
facility that is physically located in or physically connected to that
allocation area under any lease entered into under IC 36-1-10.
      (9)   For property taxes first due and payable before January 1, 2009,
this section is not applicable.
      (10)   Pay expenses incurred by the Redevelopment Commission for local
public improvements that are in the allocation area or serving the allocation
area. Public improvements include buildings, parking facilities, and other
items described in IC 36-7-14-25.1(a).
      (11)   (a)   Reimburse public and private entities for expenses incurred
in training employees of industrial facilities that are located:
            1.   In the allocation area; and
            2.   On a parcel of real property that has been classified as
industrial property under the rules of the Department of Local Government
Finance.
         (b)   However, the total amount of money spent for this purpose in any
year may not exceed the total amount of money in the allocation fund that is
attributable to property taxes paid by the industrial facilities described in
this clause. The reimbursements under this clause must be made within three
years after the date on which the investments that are the basis for the
increment financing are made.
      (12)   Pay the costs of carrying out an eligible efficiency project (as
defined in IC 36-9-41-1.5) within the unit that established the Redevelopment
Commission. However, property tax proceeds may be used under this clause to pay
the costs of carrying out an eligible efficiency project only if those property
tax proceeds exceed the amount necessary to do the following:
         (a)   Make, when due, any payments required under divisions (B)(1)
through (B)(11), including any payments of principal and interest on bonds and
other obligations payable under this section, any payments of premiums under
this section on the redemption before maturity of bonds, and any payments on
leases payable under this section.
         (b)   Make any reimbursements required under this section.
         (c)   Pay any expenses required under this section.
         (d)   Establish, augment, or restore any debt service reserve under
this section.
      (13)   Expend money and provide financial assistance as authorized in IC
36-7-14-12.2(a)(27).
      (14)   The TIF Fund may not be used for operating expenses of the
Redevelopment Commission.
   (C)   (1)   Appropriations and purchases. The Town Council of the Town of
Edinburgh may authorize the expenditure of funds from TIF - US 31 Allocation
Area Fund by appropriations made in the same manner as other funds are
appropriated that receive tax distributions, upon making a finding that the
proposed use of the funds is consistent with the intent of the Fund.
      (2)   Purchases from this Fund will be first approved by the Edinburgh
Redevelopment Commission after reviewing that the purchase is within the
permissible uses stated in this section. A claim will be created and signed by
the Redevelopment Commission president and submitted to the Clerk-Treasurer's
office for review and processing. The claim will be presented to the Edinburgh
Town Council for review and approval. Upon approval by the Town Council, the
payment will be created and sent to the vendor.
(Ord. 2021-2, passed 2-8-21)
§ 36.131 TIF - I-65 ALLOCATION AREA FUND.
   (A)   Creation of Fund 296 TIF - I-65 Allocation Area Fund. There is hereby
established a "TIF - I-65 Allocation Area Fund" to receive tax distributions
from the I-65 TIF District.
   (B)   Purposes of the Fund. Per IC 36-7-14-39(b)(4), funds from a TIF fund
may only be used by the Edinburgh Redevelopment Commission for one or more of
the following:
      (1)   Pay the principal of and interest on any obligations payable solely
from allocated tax proceeds which are incurred by the redevelopment district
for the purpose of financing or refinancing the redevelopment of that
allocation area.
      (2)   Establish, augment, or restore the debt service reserve for bonds
payable solely or in part from allocated tax proceeds in that allocation area.
      (3)   Pay the principal of and interest on bonds payable from allocated
tax proceeds in that allocation area and from the special tax levied under IC
36-7-14-27.
      (4)   Pay the principal of and interest on bonds issued by the unit to
pay for local public improvements that are physically located in or physically
connected to that allocation area.
      (5)   Pay premiums on the redemption before maturity of bonds payable
solely or in part from allocated tax proceeds in that allocation area.
      (6)   Make payments on leases payable from allocated tax proceeds in that
allocation area under IC 36-7-14-25.2.
      (7)   Reimburse the unit for expenditures made by it for local public
improvements (which include buildings, parking facilities, and other items
described in IC 36-7-14-25.1(a)) that are physically located in or physically
connected to that allocation area.
      (8)   Reimburse the unit for rentals paid by it for a building or parking
facility that is physically located in or physically connected to that
allocation area under any lease entered into under IC 36-1-10.
      (9)   For property taxes first due and payable before January 1, 2009,
this section is not applicable.
      (10)   Pay expenses incurred by the Redevelopment Commission for local
public improvements that are in the allocation area or serving the allocation
area. Public improvements include buildings, parking facilities, and other
items described in IC 36-7-14-25.1(a).
      (11)   (a)   Reimburse public and private entities for expenses incurred
in training employees of industrial facilities that are located:
            1.   In the allocation area; and
            2.   On a parcel of real property that has been classified as
industrial property under the rules of the Department of Local Government
Finance.
         (b)   However, the total amount of money spent for this purpose in any
year may not exceed the total amount of money in the allocation fund that is
attributable to property taxes paid by the industrial facilities described in
this clause. The reimbursements under this clause must be made within three
years after the date on which the investments that are the basis for the
increment financing are made.
      (12)   Pay the costs of carrying out an eligible efficiency project (as
defined in IC 36-9-41-1.5) within the unit that established the Redevelopment
Commission. However, property tax proceeds may be used under this clause to pay
the costs of carrying out an eligible efficiency project only if those property
tax proceeds exceed the amount necessary to do the following:
         (a)   Make, when due, any payments required under divisions (B)(1)
through (B)(11), including any payments of principal and interest on bonds and
other obligations payable under this section, any payments of premiums under
this subdivision on the redemption before maturity of bonds, and any payments
on leases payable under this section.
         (b)   Make any reimbursements required under this section.
         (c)   Pay any expenses required under this section.
         (d)   Establish, augment, or restore any debt service reserve under
this section.
      (13)   Expend money and provide financial assistance as authorized in IC
36-7-14-12.2(a)(27).
      (14)   The TIF Fund may not be used for operating expenses of the
Redevelopment Commission.
   (C)   Appropriations and purchases.
      (1)   The Town Council of the Town of Edinburgh may authorize the
expenditure of funds from TIF - I-65 Allocation Area Fund by appropriations
made in the same manner as other funds are appropriated that receive tax
distributions, upon making a finding that the proposed use of the funds is
consistent with the intent of the Fund.
      (2)   Purchases from this Fund will be first approved by the Edinburgh
Redevelopment Commission after reviewing that the purchase is within the
permissible uses stated in this section. A claim will be created and signed by
the Redevelopment Commission president and submitted to the Clerk-Treasurer's
office for review and processing. The claim will be presented to the Edinburgh
Town Council for review and approval. Upon approval by the Town Council, the
payment will be created and sent to the vendor.
(Ord. 2021-3, passed 2-8-21)

JOHNSON COUNTY ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT INCOME TAX (EDIT) FUND
§ 36.140 FUND ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   Creation of Fund 2216 Johnson County EDIT Fund. There is hereby
established a "Johnson County EDIT Fund". The fund shall be used to deposit
both past and future economic development income tax distributions from Johnson
County.
   (B)   Use of the funds. All funds deposited into the Johnson County EDIT
Fund shall be used according to IC 6-3.6-10-2 et seq. Those uses are:
      (1)   To pay all or a part of the interest owed by a private developer or
user on a loan extended by a financial institution or other lender to the
developer or user if the proceeds of the loan are or are to be used to finance
an economic development project;
      (2)   For the retirement of bonds for economic development projects;
      (3)   For leases or bonds entered into or issued before the date the
county economic development income tax (IC 6-3.5-7) was imposed, if the purpose
of the lease or bonds would have qualified as a purpose under this section at
the time the lease was entered into or the bonds were issued;
      (4)   The construction or acquisition of, or remedial action with respect
to, a capital project for which the unit is empowered to issue general
obligation bonds or establish a fund under any statute listed in IC 6-1.1-18.5-
9.8;
      (5)   The retirement of bonds issued under any provision of Indiana law
for a capital project;
      (6)   The payment of lease rentals under any statute for a capital
project;
      (7)   Contract payments to a nonprofit corporation whose primary
corporate purpose is to assist government in planning and implementing economic
development projects;
      (8)   Operating expenses of a governmental entity that plans or
implements economic development projects;
      (9)   Funding of a revolving fund established under IC 5-1-14-14;
      (10)   For a regional venture capital fund or a local venture capital
fund; and
      (11)   For any lawful purpose for which money in any of its other funds
may be used.
   (C)   Appropriations and purchases. The Town Council of the Town of
Edinburgh may authorize the expenditure of funds from the Johnson County EDIT
Fund by appropriations made in the same manner as other funds are appropriated
that receive distributions, upon making a finding that the proposed use of the
funds is consistent with the intent of the fund.
(Ord. 2023-8, passed 3-27-23)
JUNIOR GOLF DONATION FUND
§ 36.145 FUND ESTABLISHED.
   (A)   Creation of Fund 2595 Junior Golf Donation Fund. There is hereby
established a "Junior Golf Donation Fund". The fund shall be used to deposit
both past and future donations as well as other revenues and to disburse funds
for expenses relating to junior golf programs.
   (B)   Use of the funds. All funds deposited into the Junior Golf Donation
Fund shall be used for junior golf programs at Timbergate Golf Course including
but not limited to training aids, golf lessons, and golf equipment. Funds shall
only be used for golfers enrolled in the junior golf program. Use of funds
shall be dispersed only upon approval of a claim by the Edinburgh Town Council.
   (C)   Appropriations and purchases. The Town Council of the Town of
Edinburgh may authorize the expenditure of funds from the Junior Golf Donation
Fund by appropriations made in the same manner as other funds are appropriated
that receive donations, upon making a finding that the proposed use of the
funds is consistent with the intent of the fund.
(Ord. 2023-12, passed 9-11-23)

§ 37.01 AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH FIRE DEPARTMENT.
   (A)   The town may establish, maintain, and operate a firefighting and fire
prevention system and may provide facilities and equipment for that system.
   (B)   The town hereby establishes the Edinburgh Fire Department.
(Ord. 2019-17, passed 11-21-19)
§ 37.02 DEFINITIONS.
   For purposes of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   "FIRE CHIEF." The individual designated as the administrative head of the
agency responsible for the administration and enforcement of the fire
protection laws of the jurisdiction. For purposes of utilizing this standard,
this term shall also apply to any person specifically designated as the
authority in charge by the Fire Chief during the Fire Chief's absence.
   "FIRE DEPARTMENT." The governmental organization which is responsible for
providing fire protection services to the town.
   "FIRE HYDRANT." A valve connection on a piped water supply system having one
or more outlets and which is used to supply hose and Fire Department pumpers
with water.
   "FIRE LANE." The road or other passageway developed to allow the passage of
fire apparatus.
(Ord. 2019-17, passed 11-21-19)
§ 37.03 PURPOSE AND OBJECTIVE.
   (A)   There is hereby established a Fire Department to be supported and
equipped from appropriations by the Town Council and from other contributions.
All apparatus, equipment, and supplies of the Fire Department shall be
purchased with the approval of the Fire Chief in accordance with municipal
purchasing requirements and shall be and remain the property of the town.
   (B)   The Fire Department shall have as its objectives:
      (1)   To prevent uncontrolled fires from starting;
      (2)   To prevent the loss of life and property because of fires;
      (3)   To confine fires to their places of origin;
      (4)   To extinguish uncontrolled fires;
      (5)   To reduce morbidity and mortality from trauma, medical, and other
life-threatening emergencies by providing emergency medical care at the highest
level that the equipment and training of the personnel makes practicable;
      (6)   To perform such rescue work as its equipment and/or the training of
its personnel makes practicable;
      (7)   To provide code enforcement and building inspections as directed by
the town and the Indiana Department of Homeland Security within adopted codes
and ordinances to the extent possible that the level of equipment and training
will allow;
      (8)   To plan, prepare for, and respond to natural and man-made disasters
as part of the community's emergency management plan by serving as the
emergency management agency of the town to the extent possible that the level
of equipment and training will allow, in cooperation with the County Emergency
Management Agency and the Indiana Department of Homeland Security;
      (9)   To protect life, property, and the environment from the unintended
release of chemical, biological, and radiological hazardous chemicals and
substances to the extent possible that the level of equipment and training will
allow in cooperation with the County Emergency Management Agency and the
Indiana Department of Homeland Security;
      (10)   To plan, prepare for, and respond to terrorism threats to hometown
security based upon the anticipated risk to the community to the extent
possible that the level of equipment and training will allow and in cooperation
with the County Emergency Management Agency and the Indiana Department of
Homeland Security;
      (11)   To work with the Water Department to ensure that adequate water
supplies for fire protection are available;
      (12)   To provide public fire education materials and community risk
reduction information to the citizens of the town in order that they may
protect themselves from harm.
(Ord. 2019-17, passed 11-21-19)
§ 37.04 PERSONNEL.
   (A)   The Fire Department shall be composed of a Fire Chief appointed by the
Town Council, and such number of subordinate officers and firefighters hired by
the Town Council as may determined and recommended by the Fire Chief.
   (B)   The Fire Department shall consist of no more than five career
firefighters. In addition, the Fire department shall be supplemented by a
number of paid stand-by firefighters, with said number as determined by the
Town Council and the Fire Chief.
   (C)   All members of the Fire Department must comply with the residency
requirements of IC 36-8-4.5-4.
   (D)   Pursuant to state law, the Town Council hereby adopts an ordinance
that requires a member of the Fire Department to satisfy all of the following
residency requirements:
      (1)   Reside within one of the following counties: Johnson, Marion,
Shelby, Bartholomew, Brown and Morgan;
      (2)   Have adequate means of transportation into the town; and
      (3)   Maintain an individual telephone number with the town.
   (E)   The employees of the Fire Department shall meet all qualifications set
forth in state statutes.
   (F)   (1)   As required by IC 36-8-3.2-3, the Town Council will adopt
standards for firefighters establishing a physical agility test and a general
aptitude test. Pursuant to IC 36-8-3.2-3(c), the Town Council will present the
standards to the Board of Firefighting Personnel Standards and Education for
review.
      (2)   The Town Council or its designee, the Fire Chief, will administer
the agility and aptitude tests to applicants.
   (G)   The Fire Chief shall, under the direction of the Town Council, set up
the organization of the department, make work assignments to individuals, and
shall formulate and enforce such rules, regulations, and policies as shall be
necessary for the orderly and efficient operation of the fire department.
   (H)   The Fire Chief shall, subject to IC 36-8-2.2 and 36-8-3, have the
authority to discipline and reprimand the personnel of the Fire Department when
he or she deems such action to be necessary for the good of the Department.
   (I)   Pursuant to IC 36-8-3-4, the Town Council, as the appointing
authority, is considered the Safety Board of the town, and IC 36-8-3-4 applies
to the discipline, demotion and dismissal of members of the Fire Department.
   (J)   The Fire Chief shall be fully responsible for the training of the
firefighters and for maintenance of all apparatus, property and equipment of
the Fire Department, under the direction and subject to the requirements of the
Town Council.
   (K)   All personnel of the Fire Department, whether career or paid stand-by
shall be in compliance with the training requirements of firefighters set forth
in IC 36-8-10.5.
   (L)   Each firefighter, including all officers, shall receive no less than
ten hours of in-service firefighter training annually.
   (M)   The Town Council shall grant leaves of absences for a firefighter's
service in the Indiana General Assembly, pursuant to IC 36-8-5-2(b).
   (N)   (1)   The Town Council may grant leaves of absences for a
firefighter's service in any other elected office or, pursuant to IC 36-8-5-2
(b) and (d), for one of the following reasons for a period of up to one year:
         (a)   Sickness;
         (b)   Disability;
         (c)   Sabbatical purposes related to the improvement of the member's
professional performance and skills, such as education, special training, work
related experience, and exchange programs.
      (2)   The leave of absence may be renewed upon written request of the
member. The Town Council may determine that a member may receive compensation
pursuant to IC 36-8-5-2(f).
   (O)   As required by IC 36-8-5-2(i), the Town Council hereby adopts a
written policy that a firefighter is not entitled, during a leave of absence,
to participate in any promotional process or earn seniority. A firefighter
returning from leave shall be reinstated to the rank determined under this
policy. Except as provided by federal law, the Town Council is not required to
reinstate a firefighter in the job that the firefighter held at the time the
firefighter's leave began.
   (P)   The provisions of IC 36-8-5-3, et seq., apply to leaves of absence for
military service.
   (Q)   Pursuant to IC 36-8-8-3(b), since the town did not establish a 1937
fund for its firefighters, the town may participate in the Public Employees'
Retirement Fund ("PERF") or it may participate in the 1977 fund. The town will
take the appropriate measures for its firefighters to participate in the PERF.
   (R)   Attendance and punctuality. Firefighters shall report at their
scheduled shift start time. If the firefighter is unable to report for the
shift on time or it is necessary to call off regarding the shift, the
firefighter shall call the on-duty officer in charge to report the absence or
that the Firefighter will be arriving late. After doing so, the firefighter
shall log into Fire Manager system and submit a request for time off. The on-
duty officer in charge will be responsible for relaying this information to the
officer in charge of the shift or the Fire Chief, and will attempt to fill the
hours in the event a reported absence adversely affects staffing. Excessive
absenteeism may result in the inability to be assigned to a dedicated shift or
submit hours on the shift schedule. Excessive absenteeism may also result in
disciplinary action.
   (S)   Reserve firefighter request for time off.
      (1)   Reserve firefighters of the Department who are scheduled for a
shift or assigned to a dedicated shift may request approval for time off with
advanced notice to the officer in charge of the shift or the Fire Chief.
      (2)   In the event requested time off will adversely affect the daily
staffing, the reserve firefighter must asked to trade the hours or attempt to
give them away.
   (T)   Regular pay and overtime.
      (1)   Overtime will be paid to members of the Fire Department who are
firefighters, paramedics, EMTs, rescue workers, ambulance personnel, hazardous
material workers and reserve firefighters who have worked over 212 hours during
the Fire Department's 28-day work period.
      (2)   Other employees of the Fire Department, such as dispatchers, alarm
operators, equipment repair, maintenance workers, and others who are not
employees in fire protection activities as defined by 29 C.F.R.553.210(a) will
be paid overtime when they have worked more than 40 hours in a workweek.
      (3)   Overtime compensation is paid to all non-exempt employees at the
rate outlined in the Fair Labor Standards Act.
      (4)   Firefighters and reserve firefighters must receive authorization
from the Fire Chief or his designee prior to working unscheduled overtime. It
is the employee's responsibility to record and verify regular hours and
overtime hours on their time sheet.
      (5)   Overtime compensation will be compensated to employees at a rate
of:
         (a)   One and a half times the regular rate of pay for each hour of
overtime work (overtime pay); or
         (b)   One and one-half hours of compensatory time for each hour of
overtime work.
      (6)   Each employee has the option of receiving either overtime pay or
compensatory time off for their overtime hours worked. Employees must inform
the Fire Chief as to whether they want to receive overtime pay or compensatory
time off.
      (7)   The Fire Department retains the option to pay overtime in
additional salary in lieu of providing compensatory time off in any workweek or
work period. This substitution will not affect subsequent granting of
compensatory time off in future workweeks or work periods.
      (8)   Overtime pay will be paid along with regular pay on the employee's
paycheck. Compensatory time off will be placed in a compensatory time bank.
Employees may not accrue more than 24 hours of compensatory time.
      (9)   Payments for unused compensatory time may be made at any time and
shall be paid at the regular rate earned by the employee at the time the
employee receives such payment.
      (10)   Employees may request to use their compensatory time off. They
will be permitted to use the time off within a reasonable period after making
the request if the use does not unduly disrupt the operations of the Fire
Department.
      (11)   Upon termination of employment, the employee will be paid for
unused compensatory time at a rate not less than:
         (a)   The average regular rate received by the employee during the
last three years of employment; or
         (b)   The final regular rate received by the employee, whichever is
higher.
   (U)   Kelly Day (full time employees only).
      (1)   All full-time firefighters of the Fire Department will receive a
Kelly Day (assigned leave day) in order to partially reduce the Fair Labor
Standards Act overtime impact on the town. Kelly Days will be credited as a
leave time bank thus not to affect the employee's hourly pay rate calculations.
The employee will receive a Kelly Day during any 28-day period that the
employee is scheduled to work ten shifts.
      (2)   At times, the employee may be asked to work their Kelly Day at the
discretion of the Fire Chief in order to avoid critical staffing shortages.
Additionally, the town reserves the right to cancel or reschedule an employee's
Kelly Day during a particular 28 day work period as needed to maintain adequate
staffing levels.
   (V)   Pay schedule. Employees are paid on a weekly basis on Thursday. The
pay cycle starts on Monday and includes all hours worked through Sunday.
Employees will receive all earnings the week following the close of the weekly
payroll cycle. Any overtime earnings will be paid the first payroll date
following the completion of the 28-day Fair Labor Standards Act period.
   (W)   Time keeping rules for non-exempt employees.
      (1)   The town will maintain strict compliance with the Fair Labor
Standards Act.
      (2)   Employees must keep accurate record of all of their work hours in
the manner designated by the town (e.g., scheduling and verifying hours,
submitting signed timecards in Fire Manager). Employees must review the
accuracy of the time records before submitting them to the applicable
supervisor for processing.
      (3)   Employees are responsible for reporting accurate time records and
verifying the exact time of the beginning and end of the shift.
      (4)   Employees must obtain their supervisor's approval before working
over and above their regularly scheduled work hours. However, employees are not
required to obtain prior approval when handling emergency situations and runs
that last longer than their scheduled shift.
      (5)   In the event an employee is unable to physically sign their time
sheet, the employee's supervisor may do so with the employee's consent.
(Ord. 2019-17, passed 11-21-19; Am. Ord. 2019-19, passed 12-9-19; Am. Ord.
2020-15, passed 7-27-20)
§ 37.05 VEHICLES.
   Pursuant to IC 36-8-4.5-9, members of the Fire Department may not use
vehicles owned or maintained by their Department outside the counties in which
the town is located (Johnson County, Shelby County, and Bartholomew County)
except during the performance of official duties; or as provided for by
Department regulation.
(Ord. 2019-17, passed 11-21-19)
§ 37.06 BUDGET.
   (A)   The Fire Chief shall, under the direction of the Town Council and the
Clerk-Treasurer, prepare the annual departmental budget to be approved by the
Town Council, keep adequate records of all fires, inspections, apparatus,
equipment, personnel, training, maintenance, and work of the Fire Department.
   (B)   The Fire Chief shall submit such written reports to the Town Manager,
as the Edinburgh Town Council so requires.
(Ord. 2019-17, passed 11-21-19)
§ 37.07 JURISDICTION.
   (A)   The Fire Department shall respond to fires and other emergencies
within the town limits of the Town of Edinburgh.
   (B)   Personnel and/or equipment of the Fire Department may be used for
fighting any fire, or assisting with emergencies, outside the town limits if:
      (1)   In the opinion of the Fire Chief, the fire or emergency is in such
hazardous proximity to property owned or located within the town as to endanger
the town property;
      (2)   The town has entered into a mutual aid agreement with another
municipality; volunteer department; or district for providing emergency
services outside of the town limits.
(Ord. 2019-17, passed 11-21-19)
§ 37.08 FIRE REPORTING.
   In the event a fire occurs on any property, the owner or occupant shall
immediately report such fire to the Fire Department.
(Ord. 2019-18, passed 11-21-19)
§ 37.09 PROVISIONS OF FIRE SAFETY.
   (A)   Fire lanes. The establishment and marking of emergency fire lanes
shall be in accordance with the Town Code or other laws providing for the
establishment of no-parking zones which are in force at the time of the
establishment and marking of said emergency fire lanes.
   (B)   Obstructing the Fire Department. It shall be unlawful to hinder or
obstruct, or attempt to hinder or obstruct, any part of the fire apparatus
while the same is being taken to or from a fire or in use at a fire, or to in
any way obstruct or interfere with the use of any water supply used by the fire
department, or to hinder or prevent any firefighter from performing his work
relating to or about any fire.
   (C)   Injuring hose. It shall be unlawful to drive or park a motor vehicle
or railroad locomotive over any hose laid in any street in the vicinity of any
fire or while in use for any other purpose, or in any other way to interfere
with the use of such hose.
   (D)   Tampering with fire equipment. No person shall molest, tamper with,
damage or otherwise disturb any apparatus, equipment or appurtenance belonging
to or under the supervision and control of the Fire Department without
authority from the Fire Chief.
(Ord. 2019-18, passed 11-21-19; Am. Ord. 2023-17, passed 11-13-23)
§ 37.10 FIRE ALARMS.
   (A)   Notification of alarm activation. The Fire Department shall be
notified of the activation of any alarm.
   (B)   Faulty alarms. Whenever an alarm issues as a result of improper
installation or improper maintenance, the alarm issuer may be assessed a $50
penalty per piece of responding frrefighting apparatus for each faulty and/or
false alarm recorded within any calendar year after the occurrence of the
second faulty and/or false alarm requiring Fire Department response. Said
penalty shall be paid by the alarm user to the Clerk-Treasurer who shall
deposit the funds in the Non- Reverting Fire Fund.
      (1)   If the above fine is not paid within 30 days of its due date, then
in addition to said penalty, there shall be a late fee of $25.
      (2)   Any alarm company, alarm user, or any other individual or party
affected by and subject to a fine under this section shall have the right to
appeal the fines and penalties to the Town Council by requesting such an appeal
in writing within 30 days of the issuance of the fine. Parties must be notified
of this right to appeal at the time the fine is issued.
      (3)   The Town Council shall have the discretion to waive such fines when
in its sole discretion it determines it is in the best interest of justice and
the public interest.
   (C)   False alarms.
      (1)   For the purposes of this section, a fire alarm shall be deemed and
construed as being any act as follows: the giving, signaling, or transmission
to any public fire station or company or to any officer or employee, whether by
telephone, electronically, alarm system, spoken word, or otherwise, of
information to the effect that there is a fire, at or near the place indicated
by the person or alarm system signaling or transmitting such information.
      (2)   Whenever a false alarm issues, the alarm issuer may be assessed a
$50 penalty per piece of responding firefighting apparatus for each false and/
or faulty alarm recorded within any calendar year after the occurrence of the
second false and/or faulty alarm requiring the Fire Department's response. Said
penalty shall be paid by the alarm user to the Clerk-Treasurer who shall
deposit the funds in the Non-Reverting Fire Fund.
      (3)   If the above fine is not paid within 30 days of its due date, then
in addition to said penalty, there shall be a late fee of $25.
      (4)   Any alarm company, alarm user, or any other individual or party
affected by and subject to a fine under this section shall have the right to
appeal the fines and penalties to the Town Council by requesting such an appeal
in writing within 30 days of the issuance of the fine. Parties must be notified
of this right to appeal at the time the fine is issued.
      (5)   The Town Council shall have the discretion to waive such fines when
in its sole discretion it determines it is in the best interest of justice and
the public interest.
      (6)   It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with or injure any
fire alarm equipment maintained for the purpose of transmitting fire alarms to
the Fire Department.
      (7)   Nothing in this section shall prohibit the sounding of any signal
essential for the carrying on of any fire drill. The Fire Chief or his/her
designee must be notified at least 24 hours in advance of when a fire drill is
to take place.
   (D)   Alarm signage.
      (1)   When an alarm system is not directly connected to an approved
monitoring station, a permanent sign shall be posted above external alarm. The
sign shall read, in three-inch white letters on dark background:
WHEN ALARM SOUNDS
CALL 911
or, in an area not served by 911:
WHEN ALARM SOUNDS
CALL EDINBURGH FIRE DEPARTMENT
   (E)   Fire extinguishing systems. Automatic fire extinguishing systems, as
defined by 675 IAC 22-2.5-3(b), shall be installed if required by the Building
Code and the Fire Code. They shall be installed as required by the Building
Code and Fire Code.
   (F)   Emergency information forms. Businesses may provide emergency contact
information to the Fire Department by completing the emergency information form
that is available at the Fire Department.
(Ord. 2019-18, passed 11-21-19; Am. Ord. 2023-17, passed 11-13-23)
§ 37.11 HAZARDOUS MATERIALS RESPONSE FUND.
   (A)   The definitions set forth in IC 36-8-12.2 are hereby incorporated by
reference.
   (B)   Pursuant to IC 36-8-12.2-8.1, the Town Council hereby establishes a
Hazardous Materials Response Fund and imposes the fees and charges authorized
by IC 36-8-12.2 upon any and all responsible parties. The Fund shall be
administered by the Clerk-Treasurer and the expenses of administering the Fund
shall be paid from money in the Fund. The Fund shall be administered as
required by IC 36-8-12.2-8.1.
   (C)   The Fire Department may bill the responsible party for the total value
of the assistance provided, as determined from the State Fire Marshal's
schedule of service charges issued under IC 36-8-12-16(h).
   (D)   Money collected under IC 36-8-12.2 must be deposited into the General
Fund of the town or the Hazardous Materials Response Fund, and may only be used
for the following purposes:
      (1)   Purchase of supplies and equipment used in providing hazardous
materials emergency assistance under IC 36-8-12.2;
      (2)   Training for members of the Fire Department in skills necessary for
providing hazardous materials emergency assistance under IC 36-8-12.2; or
      (3)   Payment to persons with which the Fire Department contracts to
provide services related to the hazardous materials emergency assistance
provided by the Fire Department under IC 36-8-12.2.
(Ord. 2019-18, passed 11-21-19)
