GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 92.01 PRICE OF CEMETERY LOTS.
   The price of all lots and all other charges in the cemetery shall at all
times be fixed and determined by the Town Board of Trustees.
('83 Code, Title 2, §2.9) (Ord. 242, passed 9-5-1912; Am. Ord. 1987-3, passed
2-23-87; Am. Ord. 1988-15, passed 11-11-88)
§ 92.02 PERPETUAL CARE FUND.
   (A)   There is created a Perpetual Care Fund for the care, maintenance, and
upkeep of Rest Haven Cemetery located in the town. This fund is to be
designated on the books and records of the Town Board and on the books and
records of Rest Haven Cemetery as the Perpetual Care Fund.
   (B)   The Perpetual Care Fund shall be maintained by the addition to the
fund of sums of money obtained pursuant to the sale of grave sites in an amount
established by the Town Board of Trustees.
('83 Code, Title 2, §2.7) (Ord. 242, passed 8-5-1912; Am. Ord. 1981-8, passed
8-11-81; Am. Ord. 1987-3, passed 2-23-87; Am. Ord. 1988-15, passed 11-11-88)
BOARD OF CEMETERY TRUSTEES
§ 92.10 ESTABLISHMENT AND DUTIES.
   There is hereby created a board to be known as the Board of Trustees of the
Edinburgh Cemetery to advise the Town Board of Trustees on the use of privately
donated funds to the Edinburgh Cemetery. Said Board shall consist of five
members to be appointed by the Town Board of Trustees.
('83 Code, Title 2, §2.l) (Ord. 242, passed 8-5-1912; Am. Ord. 1987-3, passed
2-23-87; Am. Ord. 1988-15, passed 11-11-88)
§ 92.11 MEMBERS.
   (A)   The members of the Cemetery Board shall be either residents of the
town, or owners of lots within the cemetery, either by purchase or by
inheritance. Further, one of the members of the Board shall be a member of the
Town Board of Trustees and shall, by virtue of his office, be President of the
Board of Cemetery Trustees.
('83 Code, Title 2, §2.2) (Ord. 242, passed 8-5-1912; Am. Ord. 322, passed 7-1-
40; Am. Ord. 1973-1, passed 2-12-73; Am. Ord. 1987-3, passed 2-23-87; Am. Ord.
1988-15, passed 11-11-88)
   (B)   The Board of Trustees of the cemetery shall consist of five suitable
persons, having the qualifications set forth in this chapter, each of whom
shall serve for a term of four years from the date of their appointment. The
Town Board of Trustees shall, at their regular session in the month of January
in each year, appoint one or two persons as the case may require, to serve as
members of the Cemetery Board of Trustees.
('83 Code, Title 2, §2.3) (Ord. 242, passed 8-5-1912; Am. Ord. 1973-1, passed
2-12-73; Am. Ord. 1987-3, passed 2-23-87; Am. Ord. 1988-15, passed 11-11-18)
§ 92.12 POWERS AND DUTIES; COMPENSATION.
   The Board of Trustees of the cemetery shall be allowed compensation for
their services as the Town Board of Trustees from year to year shall determine.
('83 Code, Title 2, §2.4) (Ord. 242, passed 8-5-1912; Am. Ord. 1987-3, passed
2-23-87; Am. Ord. 1988-15, passed 11-11-18)
§ 92.13 SECRETARY AND SEXTON.
   (A)   The Town Board of Trustees may, on or before January 21 of each year,
employ a secretary to the Board of Cemetery Trustees, which person shall be a
resident of the town and shall serve as secretary upon the terms and conditions
determined by the Town Board of Trustees and specifically at the pleasure of
the Town Board of Trustees until his successor is elected and qualified. That
secretary may be a member of the Cemetery Board of Trustees. ('83 Code, Title
2, §2.5)
(Ord. 242, passed 8-5-1912; Am. Ord. 1973-1, passed 2-12-73; Am. Ord. 1987-3,
passed 2-23-87; Am. Ord. 1988-15, passed 11-11-18)
   (B)   The secretary, if employed, shall give bond in the sum of $2,500 in
favor of the town to account of all moneys and property of all kinds coming
into his hands as secretary and shall have such duties as the Town Board shall
proscribe.
   (C)   The sexton, if employed, shall give bond in the sum of $2,500 in favor
of the town to account for all moneys and property of all kinds coming into his
hands as sexton and shall have such duties as the Town Board shall proscribe.
(Ord. 1988-15, passed 11-11-18)

GARBAGE COLLECTION
§ 93.01 DEFINITION; STORAGE OF SOME ITEMS PROHIBITED.
   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   "GARBAGE."
      (1)   Any and every accumulation of vegetable or animal matter, either
liquid or solid, which is received from residential kitchens, tin cans, waste
paper, broken glass, bottles, jars, grass, straw, dishes, clothing or cloth
materials.
      (2) "GARBAGE," for the purposes of this subchapter, shall not mean
discarded gun shells, metal or fibrous shavings, ashes, cinders, dead animals,
trees or parts thereof, automotive materials, building materials, appliances,
old furniture, carpet, brush, concrete, bricks or masonry materials. Said items
may not be stored outside in any zoning district.
(Ord. 1977-16, passed 9-14-77; Am. Ord. 20-1984, passed 11-26-84; Am. Ord.
2010-7, passed 3-8-10)   Penalty, see §10.99
§ 93.02 SERVICE PROVIDED TO RESIDENTIAL LOCATIONS.
   The town shall provide to every residential location within the town's
corporate boundaries, weekly garbage pickup service, or shall cause same to be
provided to persons residing in the residential locations in the town.
(Ord. 1977-16, passed 9-14-77)   Penalty, see §10.99
§ 93.03 MANNER OF PLACEMENT; CONFORMANCE REQUIRED.
   (A) Manner of placement of collection. All garbage shall be placed in a
container supplied by the town trash service provider.
   (B)   It shall be the responsibility of the owners or occupier of each
residence within the town to insure that such property is free from trash,
garbage and/or rubbish ad to keep the sidewalks and alleys adjacent to such
property free of trash, garbage rubbish and/or yard waste except as otherwise
provided.
   (C)   Containers shall be placed not earlier than 24 hours to the pickup day
and removed not later than 24 hours following regular trash pickup day.
   (D)   It is unlawful for any person or business to use the container of
another person or business of a town owned receptacle for the disposal of
trash, garbage, rubbish or yard waste. It shall be the responsibility of the
owner or occupier of the property to notify the Police Department of such
violation.
   (E)   Conformity required. Any garbage placed at the street or curb line for
removal by the town will not be removed by the town unless it conforms to the
provisions of this subchapter. Any person placing garbage at the curb line or
street for collection in violation of any of the provisions of this subchapter,
may be held liable for the accumulation of trash and filth upon private
property and be subject to penalties provided for in §10.99
(Ord. 1977-16, passed 9-14-77; Am. Ord. 2019-6, passed 4-22-19) Penalty, see
§10.99
§ 93.04 GARBAGE EXPOSED TO FLIES, RODENTS, OR THE LIKE PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any owner or lessee of any lot or parcel of land
within the corporate boundaries of the town, to place, deposit, or permit to be
deposited, any human or animal excrement, garbage, or any other organic waste
upon the premises in such a way or place that it is exposed to flies or other
insects, rodents, small domestic animals, or will endanger a water supply.
(Ord. 1977-16, passed 9-14-77) Penalty, see §10.99
§ 93.05 COSTS OF COLLECTION.
   (A)   The residences of the town are divided into fair and reasonable types
according to their structure and uses, for the purposes of garbage and trash
accumulation. All collections will be made as provided in this subchapter.
   (B)   Fees for regular collection shall be as approved by the Town Council
of the Town of Edinburgh.
   (C)   Determination of how many apartments shall be made based upon the
number of electrical meters.
   (D)   Garbage collection fees at residences where a portion of the building
is used for commercial purposes shall be increased $3 per month. The refuse
fees shall be included within the electric utility bill to each electric user
monthly. The electric utility is directed not to accept payment of the electric
bill unless such payment is in the total amount billed, which shall include the
appropriate garbage collection fee as herein provided.
   (E)   Owners or occupants of premises which do not use electricity shall be
billed monthly by separate billing for the appropriate refuse fees for their
premises. All accounts due are subject to the same penalty provisions as the
electric utility fees, if not paid on or before the expiration of the past due
dates shown on the bill.
   (F)   The charges fixed in this section for the collection, removal, and
disposal of all garbage shall be entered in the respective amounts as charged
against each owner, manager, occupant, tenant, or lessee, and the amount so
fixed and charged shall be collected monthly in connection with and as part of
the electric utility bill. Should any owner, manager, occupant, tenant, or
lessee of any place or abode, fail or refuse to part the charges fixed against
him and his place of abode, when due, the town shall have the right to
disconnect the electric service to his place of abode, against which the
garbage collection fees and electric utility fees have been fixed and assessed.
(Ord. 1981-1, passed 1-13-81)
   (G)   (1)   A customer disputing the correctness of his bill shall have a
right to a hearing at which time he may be represented in person and by counsel
or any other person of his choosing and may present orally or in writing his
complaint and contentions to the town official in charge of sewer delinquent
utility billing who shall be authorized to order that the customer's service
not be discontinued and authority to make a final determination of the
customer's complaint.
      (2)   Requests for delays or waiver of payment will not be entertained;
only questions of proper and correct billing will be considered. In the absence
of payment of the bill rendered or resort to the hearing procedure provided
herein, service will be discontinued at the time specified.
(Am. Ord. 1998-2, passed 3-23-98)
§ 93.06 CERTAIN PERSONS EXEMPT FROM COLLECTION FEE.
   It is the intent of the town, that the garbage collection fee shall not be
assessed against any user in whose name the electric meter is installed, who is
either 65 years old or older or who is on full disability from the Social
Security Administration. To accomplish the purpose and intent of this section,
any garbage collection user is entitled to file with the Clerk-Treasurer Is
office, an affidavit provided by the Clerk-Treasurer's office upon the showing
of proof of age or a full disability from the Social Security Administration to
be exempted from the charge. Also exempt from the trash collection fees, will
be any residence at the time of enactment where regular garbage collection does
not occur as a result of a private licensed pick-up service or scavenger
service presently removing or picking up garbage. The above stated exception
shall not apply to the charges incurred for violation of the large semi-annual
trash pick-up described in §93.16.
(Ord. 1981-1, passed 1-13-81; Am. Ord. 1998-2, passed 3-23-98)
TRASH COLLECTION
§ 93.15 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definition shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   "TRASH." Cans, bottles, waste paper, glass, old furniture or mattresses,
grass clippings, discarded gun shells, metal or fibrous shavings, ashes,
cinders, straw, dishes, or cloth materials. "TRASH," for purposes of this
chapter, shall not mean dead animals, trees or parts thereof, automotive
materials, building materials, appliances, concrete, bricks, or masonry
materials.
(Ord. 1977-16, passed 9-14-77)
§ 93.16 SERVICE PROVIDED TO RESIDENTIAL LOCATIONS DURING CERTAIN MONTHS.
   The town shall provide or cause to be provided to every residential location
within the town's corporate boundaries, trash collection which shall be deemed
the "Semi-Annual Large Trash Pick-Up" on such dates as published by the Town
Council but no more two times per year at no costs to persons residing in the
residential locations in the Town. The large semi-annual trash pick-up is for
the specific purpose of disposing of larger items including but not limited to
appliances, furniture and larger items not normally disposed of by residential
trash collection. Provided, however, that the Town Council shall publish the
dates for the semi-annual large trash pick-up and items to be picked up shall
not be placed on the street for collection more than 72 hours prior to the
beginning of the large semi-annual trash pick-up. That in the event that the
items are placed in an open location visible to near the normal site pick-up
prior to 72 hours the Town shall notify the owner of the real estate to remove
the items until the designated placement time of 72 hours prior to the
beginning of the pick-up time. That in the event the owner does not cause the
items to be removed within 72 hours of the Town posting a notice on the
residence at or near the front door of the residence and/or apartment building
and the notice shall be sufficient notice to the owner to remove the items
within 72 hours of the posting of the notice. That in the event the items are
not removed to be in conformance with the provisions hereunder the Town shall
cause the same to be removed and charge the owner of the property the cost of
the removal. The cost shall be added to the water bill of the property and
shall be collected at the next water bill payment date. That the water utility
is directed not to accept payment of the water bill unless such payment is in
the total amount billed which shall include the appropriate trash collection
charges as described herein.
(Ord. 1977-16, passed 9-14-77; Am. Ord. 1998-2, passed 3-23-98)
§ 93.17 MANNER OF PLACEMENT; CONFORMANCE REQUIRED.
   (A)   Manner of placement of collection. All garbage shall be placed in a
container supplied by the town trash service provider.
   (B)   Conformity required. Any trash placed at the street or curb line for
removal by the town, will not be removed by the town unless it conforms to the
provisions of this chapter. Any person placing trash at the curb line or street
for collection in violation of any of the provisions of this subchapter, may be
held liable for the accumulation of trash and filth upon private property and
be subject to penalties provided for in §10.99.
(Ord. 1977-16, passed 9-14-77; Am. Ord. 2019-6, passed 4-22-19) Penalty, see
§10.99

dirt, concrete, bricks, rocks, or lumber over eight feet in length.

RECYCLING DEPOT
§ 93.45 ITEMS PROHIBITED FROM DEPOT.
   (A)   The following is a list of items that are only allowed at the
Edinburgh Recycling Depot:
      (1)   Flattened cardboard;
      (2)   Clean plastic bottles and jugs;
      (3)   Mixed paper;
      (4)   Newspapers;
      (5)   Magazines;
      (6)   Paperboard boxes; and
      (7)   Clean food and beverage cans.
   (B)   All other materials and items not included in division (A) are
strictly prohibited and shall not be deposited in the Edinburgh Recycling
Depot.
(Ord. 2020-7, passed 2-24-20)
§ 93.46 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   The Edinburgh Recycling Depot will be in operation on Tuesdays, 10:00 a.m.
to 6:00 p.m., Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. and the first and third Saturdays
of the month, 8:00 a.m. to 1:00 p.m.
(Ord. 2020-7, passed 2-24-20)

93.45, and/or depositing any materials or items outside of the hours of
operation provided in §
93.46, shall be subject to the following penalties:
   (A)   Initial fine of $225;
   (B)   Fines not to exceed $1,000 for each additional offense;
   (C)   Any and all cost and expenses the Town of Edinburgh incurs to remedy
the violation.
(Ord. 2020-7, passed 2-24-20)
CHAPTER 94: NUISANCES
Section
   
94.01 Maintaining nuisances prohibited
   
94.02 Certain prohibited nuisances designated
   
94.03 Notice to abate
   
94.04 Request for hearing
   
94.05 Failure to abate
   
94.06 Collection of cost of abatement
§ 94.01 MAINTAINING NUISANCES PROHIBITED.
   No person shall erect, construct, cause, permit, keep, or maintain within
the town limits, anything whatsoever which is injurious to the public health or
safety, or offensive to the senses of inhabitants, or an obstacle to the free
use of property by such inhabitants. The existence of any of the above is
declared to be a nuisance and shall be regulated as set forth in this chapter.
('83 Code, Title 7, §5.l)
§ 94.02 CERTAIN PROHIBITED NUISANCES DESIGNATED.
   The following are declared to be nuisances, but shall not be construed to
prevent any other thing from being declared a nuisance pursuant to the
standards of §94.01 of this chapter:
   (A)   The erecting or using of any building or other place for the exercise
of any trade, employment, or manufacture, which by occasioning noxious
exhalations, dense smoke or ash, or other annoyances, becomes harmful to the
health, safety, or property of individuals or the public;
   (B)   Causing or suffering any offal, filth, or waste to be collected or to
remain in any place to the prejudice of others;
   (C)   The obstructing or encumbering by any means whatsoever the private
ways and the public streets, alleys, and places so as to create a physical
threat to the public;
   (D)   Billboards, signboards, and advertising signs, whether erected and
constructed on public or private property, or overhanging branches or
vegetation, which so obstruct and impair the view of any portion of a public
street or alley of the town as to render dangerous the use thereof;
   (E)   Garbage and rubbish. All putrid waste materials of every kind,
including but not limited to such items as tree trimmings, cans, glass, paper,
appliances, tires, wheels, metal devices and parts;
   (F)   Unwholesome substance. Garbage, rubbish and any other putrescible
material which may provide food or breeding places for rats, mice and other
disease-carrying animals or insects.
('83 Code, Title 7, §5.2) (Am. Ord. 2019-4, passed 3-25-19)
§ 94.03 NOTICE TO ABATE.
   (A)   Any residence and/or surrounding property therein containing any such
materials, including but not limited to such items referenced in the
definitions or designated nuisances as provided in §94.02, shall receive
notification of such violation. Whenever the Town Marshal finds that a nuisance
exists, he shall cause to be served upon the property owner, as shown by the
records of the County Auditor, a written notice to abate the nuisance within a
reasonable time after such notice. Such notice shall be sent to the property
owner by certified mail. ('83 Code, Title 7, §5.3)
   (B)   The notice to abate shall contain:
      (1)   A description of what constitutes the nuisance;
      (2)   The location of the nuisance;
      (3)   A statement of the act or acts necessary to abate the nuisance;
      (4)   A reasonable time within which to complete the abatement; and
      (5)   A statement that if the nuisance is not abated as directed and no
request for hearing is made within the time prescribed, the town will abate it
and assess the costs against the property owner.
('83 Code, Title 7, §5.4) (Am. Ord. 2019-4, passed 3-25-19)
§ 94.04 REQUEST FOR HEARING.
   (A)   Any person ordered to abate a nuisance may have a hearing with the
officer ordering the abatement to determine whether a nuisance does exist. A
request for a hearing must be made in writing and delivered to the officer
ordering the abatement within the time stated in the notice, or it will be
conclusively presumed that a nuisance exists that must be abated as ordered.
   (B)   At the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer shall render a
written decision as to whether a nuisance exists. If he finds that a nuisance
exists, he must order it abated within an additional time which must be
reasonable under the circumstances. An appeal from this decision may be had by
immediately filing a written notice with the hearing officer. This appeal will
be heard before the Town Board of Trustees at a time and place fixed by the
Town Board of Trustees. The findings of the Town Board of Trustees shall be
conclusive and, if a nuisance is found to exist, it shall be ordered abated
within a time reasonable under the circumstances.
('83 Code, Title 7, §5.5)
§ 94.05 FAILURE TO ABATE.
   If the person notified to abate a nuisance neglects or fails to abate as
directed, the town may perform the action required to abate, keeping an
accurate account of the expenses incurred. An itemized expense account shall be
certified and filed with the designated town official.
('83 Code, Title 7, §5.6)
§ 94.06 COLLECTION OF COST OF ABATEMENT.
   The designated town official shall send a statement by certified mail of the
total expense incurred to the property owner who has failed to abide by the
notice to abate, and if the amount shown by the statement has not been paid
within one month, he shall certify the costs to the County Auditor. The amount
due shall then be collected with, and in the same manner as general property
taxes and disbursed into the General Fund of the town.
('83 Code, Title 7, §5.7)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 95.01 ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES PROHIBITED IN PUBLIC PARKS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to bring, possess, or consume alcoholic
beverages in any public parks within the town.
(Ord. 1978-8, passed 7-10-78)   Penalty, see §95.99
§ 95.02 TRESPASSING OR FISHING AT TIMBERGATE GOLF COURSE.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to do the following on the
Timbergate Golf Course:
      (1)   Trespass on any part of the grounds of the Timbergate Golf Course;
      (2)   Fish or attempt to fish any of the ponds contained on the
Timbergate Golf Course;
      (3)   Access or use any part of the Timbergate Golf Course without the
expressed consent of the town and its agents.
   (B)   For purposes of this section, "TRESPASS" is defined by IC 35-43-2-2.
(Ord. 2011-11, passed 7-25-11)   Penalty, see §95.99
§ 95.03 TRESPASSING AT THE BLUE RIVER DAM.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to do the following regarding the
Blue River Dam (“dam”);
      (1)   Trespass on any part of the dam;
      (2)   Trespass on any real property owned by the town that is adjacent to
the dam;
      (3)   Gain access to areas of the dam by way of access points owned by
the town; or
      (4)   Access or use any part of dam without the expressed consent of the
town or its agents.
   (B)   For purposes of this section, “TRESPASS” is defined by IC 35-43-2-2.
(Ord. 2013-8, passed 10-28-13)   Penalty, see §95.99
DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION
§ 95.15 ESTABLISHMENT.
   Under the provisions of the Park and Recreation Laws of the state, IC 36-10-
3-1 et seq., there is established a Department of Parks and Recreation composed
of the Board of Parks and Recreation and such other personnel as the Board
shall determine necessary.
(Ord. 1980-12, passed 12-29-80; Am. Ord. 1983-2, passed 5-10-83)
§ 95.16 MEMBERS.
   The Board of Parks and Recreation shall be composed of four members to be
selected by the President of the Town Board of Trustees on the basis of their
interest in knowledge of parks and recreation. Not more than two members may be
affiliated with the same political party.
(IC 36-10-3-4(a)) (Ord. 1980-12, passed 12-29-80)
§ 95.17 TERMS.
   Upon the establishment of the Board of Parks and Recreation, the terms of
the members initially appointed shall be one, two, three, and four years.
Thereafter, as a term expires, each new appointment or reappointment shall be
for a four-year term. All terms shall expire on the first Monday of January,
but an appointee shall continue in office until his successor is appointed.
(IC 36-10-3-5) (Ord. 1980-12, passed 12-29-80)
§ 95.18 OFFICERS.
   At its first regular meeting in each year, the Board of Parks and Recreation
shall elect a President and a Vice-President, and the Vice- President shall
have authority to act as the President of the Board during the absence or
disability of the President. The Board may select a secretary either from
within or outside its membership.
(IC 36-10-3-8(c)) (Ord. 1980-12, passed 12-29-80)
§ 95.19 POWERS.
   The Board of Parks and Recreation shall have all powers provided under the
laws of the state, including those provided in IC 36-10-3-10, 36-10-3-11, and
36-10-3-12.
(Ord. 1980-12, passed 12-29-80)
§ 95.20 BUDGET, FUNDING.
   The Board of Parks and Recreation shall prepare and submit an annual budget
in the same manner as departments of any departmentalized governmental unit.
The Board may accept gifts, donations, and subsidies for park and recreation
purposes.
(Ord. 1980-12, passed 12-29-80)
§ 95.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person convicted of violating §95.01 may be fined not less than $1
nor more than $500.
(Ord. 1978-8, passed 7-10-78)
   (B)   Any person who violates §95.02 by trespassing on the Timbergate Golf
Course or attempting to fish on the ponds contained within the Timbergate Golf
Course shall be guilty of an ordinance violation in the amount of $500 for each
such violation.
(Ord. 2011-11, passed 7-25-11)
   (C)   Any person who violates §95.03 shall be guilty of an ordinance
violation in the amount of $50 for each such violation.
(Ord. 2013-8, passed 10-28-13)

GENERAL PROVISIONS
§ 96.01 DEFINITION.
   For the purpose of this chapter the following definition shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   "STREET." All public roads and highways in the town.
('83 Code, Title 6, §3.l)
§ 96.02 OBSTRUCTING PUBLIC WAYS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to in any manner obstruct any street, or
alley crossing, or for any number of persons to congregate at any point upon
any sidewalk in the town so as to hinder or interfere with the free passage of
pedestrians thereon.
('83 Code, Title 6, §3.3)   Penalty, see §96.99
§ 96.03 OBSTRUCTING STREET DRAINS OR GUTTERS PROHIBITED.
   It shall be unlawful for the owner or occupant of any real estate within the
town, or any person, to obstruct, cause, or suffer the obstruction of any
ditch, drain, or gutter, made by authority of the town, running along side, in
front of, or through any such real estate, or in any street.
('83 Code, Title 6, §3.2)   Penalty, see §96.99
§ 96.04 DAMAGE TO STREETS.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to injure, remove, or displace, or cause
to be injured, removed, or displaced, any earth, stone, gravel, or other
material forming a part of any street, sidewalk, or alley, or to damage,
remove, or deface any appurtenance in any street or alley within the town,
without permission so to do from the Board of Trustees.
('83 Code, Title 6, §3.4)   Penalty, see §96.99
§ 96.05 STRUCTURES AFFIXED TO SIDEWALKS PROHIBITED.
   The construction or use of any structure of support, any awning, or overhang
attached to any building which is permanently affixed to the sidewalk and to
the awning or overhangs in front of the building and more than 12 inches from
the curb is declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. Every person having
such structure in a sidewalk shall remove the same not later than ten days
after a receipt of written notice so to do from the Clerk-Treasurer.
('83 Code, Title 6, §3.6)   Penalty, see §96.99
§ 96.06 AWNINGS, SIGNS, OR OTHER OVERHANGING STRUCTURES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person occupying any building to maintain any
awning, sign, or thing of like nature over the sidewalk in front of such
building so that any part of the same is less than seven feet above the surface
of the sidewalk over which it is so hung.
('83 Code, Title 6, §3.7)   Penalty, see §96.99
STREET EXCAVATIONS
§ 96.20 PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE.
   (A)   Permit.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person to cut, dig, or excavate in any
part of any street or alley right-of-way within the town, except for the
purpose of making installations therein under contract with the town, without
first filing with the Town Superintendent a written application for a permit to
make such a cut or excavation at least three days in advance of the time of
beginning the work to be done under such permit; except, that when an emergency
exists, the applicant may secure such permit in less than such three- day
period by stating in his application the exact emergency. All permits shall be
submitted to and be approved by the Town Superintendent prior to being filed
with the Clerk-Treasurer. Such application shall particularly describe the
exact location, kind, dimension by feet and inches, the type of road surface to
be cut or excavated, the nature of the opening to be made, and the exact
purpose of the proposed work.
      (2)   All applicants must pay a $10 permit and inspection fee at the time
the permit is filed. The permit shall be valid for 90 days after approval is
given by the Town Superintendent.
      (3)   Any and all work performed within the street or alley right-of-way
in connection with such excavation, such as forcing pipe under pavement,
trenches between the curb and sidewalks, or trenches outside the paved macadam,
oiled, or graveled surfaces of a street or alley, are covered by this
subchapter and shall require a permit.
('83 Code, Title 6, §3.5(a))
   (B)   The approval of a permit to cut into a street or alley does not
authorize entry into a public sewer or drain, or prejudice the town's right to
require the removal or relocations of structures, wire, pipes, or appurtenances
installed in connection with such permit. ('83 Code, Title 6, §3.5(e))
(Ord. 15-1967, passed 9-21-77)   Penalty, see §96.99
§ 96.21 BOND REQUIRED.
   The Town Council members, or designee designated by the Town Council shall,
in their discretion, require any party who, as a result of the activities of
themselves, their agents, contractors, or anyone else working for them or in
their behalf, either damages, obstructs, or encumbers and street, alley, or
public place in the town or by their expressed intentions, commit themselves to
engage in activities which might result in damage, obstruction, or encumbrance,
to post a bond or other surety payable to the town in such sum and to cover
such length of time as Town Council and other town officials in their
discretion so deem.
('83 Code, Title 6, §3.5(b)) (Ord. 15-1967, passed 9-21-77; Am. Ord. 2019-15,
passed 11-12-19)
§ 96.22 INAPPLICABILITY OF REGULATIONS TO TOWN EMPLOYEES.
   The sections of this subchapter shall not apply to the officers or employees
of the town when prosecuting any work by order of or under the direction of the
Town Superintendent or the Town Board of Trustees.
('83 Code, Title 6, §3.5(g)) (Ord. 15-1967, passed 9-21-77)
§ 96.23 ADMINISTRATION OF REGULATIONS.
   It shall be the duty of the Town Council, or designee designated by the Town
Council to have printed such form and instructions as are required for the
administration of this subchapter. It shall be the duty of the Clerk-Treasurer
to require all persons making application for a permit under the terms of the
bonds required hereby.
('83 Code, Title 6, §3.5(f)) (Ord. 15-1967, passed 9-21-77; Am. Ord. 2019-15,
passed 11-12-19)
§ 96.24 NONCOMPLIANCE TO RESULT IN ORDER TO STOP WORK.
   (A)   One copy of each permit shall be issued to the following individuals:
The applicant, the Clerk-Treasurer, and the Town Superintendent.
   (B)   It shall be the specific duty of the Town Superintendent to stop any
work which is being performed when it does not comply with the terms of this
subchapter or the conditions stipulated on the permit and report such
noncompliance to the Town Board of Trustees for further action.
('83 Code, Title 6, §3.5(c)) (Ord. 15-1967, passed 9-21-77)
§ 96.25 SUPERVISION.
   The operation of excavating, or in any manner changing the surface of, any
sidewalk, street, alley or other public place within the town, and the
refilling and resurfacing of any excavation, shall be done under the
supervision of the designee designated by the Town Council and Street
Superintendent.
('83 Code, Title 6, §3.5(d)) (Ord. 15-1967, passed 9-21-77; Am. Ord. 2019-15,
passed 11-12-19)
§ 96.26 REPAIRS.
   (A)   All excavations in street shall be repaired according to the type of
the existing surface as follows:
      (1)   Existing asphalt surface:
         (a)   Excavation shall be filled with thoroughly compacted sand to a
depth not less than ten inches below finished grade;
         (b)   Portland cement concrete with a 3,000 psi minimum shall be
deposited on top of the sand fill to within one inch below finished grade;
         (c)   After portland cement concrete has cured for a minimum period of
four days, asphaltic primer RC-3 shall be applied at a rate of 0.5 gallons per
square yard;
         (d)   A one-inch course of hot asphaltic concrete, Indiana State
Highway Department, Type B shall be applied, thoroughly compacted and rolled.
If the weather is unsuitable for properly applying hot asphaltic concrete for
repairing the surface, a temporary patch may be applied consisting of asphalt
coated aggregate (cold patch), provided that when suitable paving weather
occurs, the temporary patching materials shall be removed and replaced with hot
asphaltic concrete as specified above.
      (2)   Existing concrete surface:
         (a)   Excavation shall be filled with thoroughly compacted sand to a
depth not less than eight inches below finished grade;
         (b)   Portland cement concrete with a 3000 psi minimum shall be placed
in the remaining cavity and troweled with a wooden float to finish grade.
      (3)   Existing aggregate surface:
         (a)   Excavation shall be filled with sand up to a depth not less than
eight inches below finished grade;
         (b)   The remaining depth shall be filled with crushed stone of the
size required by the designated designee by Town Council or Street
Superintendent.
      (4)   Existing earth surface: Excavation shall be filled with earth, and
earth mounded above the excavation to a height above finished grade amounting
to 10% of the depth of the excavation. After settling has occurred, earth shall
be added or removed to level the fill with finished grade, and the surface
restored to the same condition as existed before excavation was made.
   (B)   Exploratory drill holes shall be filled in the same manner as trench
or pit excavations, except that when the holes are made in an existing earth
surface, it shall be refilled with sand except under six inches of fill
material, which shall be earth.
   (C)   Excavation under shall sidewalks shall be refilled with fully
compacted sand to a level four inches below finished grade of the sidewalk in
pedestrian traveled areas and six inches below finished grade of sidewalk in
driveway areas. The sidewalk shall be replaced to the same as that removed and
to a depth of four or six inches respectively in pedestrian and driveway areas.
Sidewalk material shall be portland cement concrete, air-entraining type, 3000
psi. strength, finished with a wooden flute and steel edding tool and scored to
match adjacent sidewalk scoring.
(Ord. 2019-15, passed 11-12-19)
§ 96.27 STREET CUTS.
   All cuts made in the driving area of a street or alley shall be covered with
steel plates and anchored safely to the paved surface until the cut is ready
for traffic. Cold-patch type asphalt concrete shall be placed all around the
plate to lessen any possible damage to the vehicles crossing the area. No more
than ten calendar days shall elapse between the date the hole is first cut in
the street right-of-way and the date on which the repair is complete and the
patch is paved to finished grade and open to traffic.
(Ord. 2019-15, passed 11-12-19)
§ 96.28 RESURFACING OF ENTIRE STREET.
Any utility company, contractor, or individual causing a total of five or more
holes, a maximum of three feet, or a trench or trenches totaling 30 feet in
length to be made in an average of 300-foot long city block during one 12-month
period shall be required to resurface the entire width of the street or alley
for the full town block within the current paving season with a one-inch
thickness of surface-type hot asphaltic concrete. The existing paved surface
shall be tack coated before paving.
(Ord. 2019-15, passed 11-12-19)
§ 96.29 FAILURE OF REPAIRS.
   (A)   If the place or places where the excavation and repairs are refilled
or replaced under the provisions of the subchapter fall within the life of the
street pavement or before the street is repaved by the town, the permittee
shall, at his/her own expense within ten days after receipt of written notice
from the Clerk-Treasurer, or other designee designated by Town Council, refill
and resurface it.
   (B)   If the permittee fails to refill or resurface after the receipt of ten
days written notice, the town shall make the necessary repairs and render a
statement of charges to the permittee which statement shall be due and payable
within 30 days after receipt of the statement.
(Ord. 2019-15, passed 11-12-19)
§ 96.30 COST.
   The entire expense of excavating, or in any manner changing, the surface of
any sidewalk, street, curb, alley, or public place within the town shall be
borne by the permittee. The town shall not be liable for any expenses incurred
therefrom, nor for any injury or damages caused to any person or property.
(Ord. 2019-15, passed 11-12-19)
SNOW REMOVAL
§ 96.35 REMOVAL OF SNOW ON SIDEWALKS.
   Any person owning, occupying, or controlling any lot, part of lot, or other
real estate in the town abutting on any sidewalk shall remove from the sidewalk
any snow or ice that may fall or accumulate thereon within six hours after such
snow or ice has so fallen or accumulated thereon, provided that such person
shall not be required to remove such snow or ice between the hours of 5:00 p.m.
and 7:00 a.m. of the following morning in the event such snow or ice shall fall
or accumulate at such time that it may not be removed before 5:00 p.m.
('83 Code, Title 6, §3.8(a))   Penalty, see §96.99
§ 96.36 REMOVAL BY TOWN; LIABILITY OF OWNER.
   If any person shall fail to remove any snow or ice from any improved
sidewalk within the time provided for in this subchapter, the Street
Commissioner may remove such snow and ice and he shall keep an accurate account
of the time employed in so doing and the expense thereof. The owner of the lot,
part of the lot, or other real estate shall be liable to the town in an action
against the person for the reasonable costs and expenses thereof, together with
the costs of the action.
('83 Code, Title 6, §3.8(b)) (Am. Ord. 1990-1, passed 2-26-90)
§ 96.99 PENALTY.
   (A)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter for which no penalty is
otherwise provided, shall be subject to the penalty set forth in §10.99. A
separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day that a violation occurs
or continues.
   (B)   Any person who shall violate §96.35 shall upon conviction thereof be
fined in any sum not exceeding $10. ('83 code, Title 6, §3.8(a))
